newsitem.title: UK: It's true what they say about an apple a day....
newsitem.headline: It's true what they say about an apple a day....

text.p: The old adage that an apple a day keeps the doctor away is true, doctors reported on Friday -- people who eat fresh fruit every day have fewer heart attacks.
A Europe-wide study of diet and health also found that meat-eaters are more likely to be obese.
The study, published in the British Medical Journal, added to a growing weight of evidence that people's bodies need a steady input of fresh fruit and vegetables.

Britain's Imperial Cancer Research Fund (ICRF) and Medical Research Council are doing a study of 11,000 "health-conscious" people recruited through health-food stores, clinics and vegetarian societies.

Interim results published on Friday show that, over a 17-year period, there were 32 percent fewer stroke deaths among people who ate fresh fruit every day compared to those who did not. They found a 24 percent drop in heart attack deaths and a 21 percent deacrease in deaths of all kinds.
"This study shows that if you do eat fresh fruit daily, the chances of dying from a heart attack or stroke are significantly reduced," said one of the report's authors, Dr Tim Key.
"It's a simple message which supports the old saying "an apple a day...'"
Key added that there was also evidence fresh fruit protects against cancer and the study would be looking at this.
In the second half of the study, 21,000 people classified as meat-eaters, fish-eaters, vegetarians or vegans were monitored for obesity, defined as being 20 percent over ideal weight.

"Within the group of meat-eaters 9.2 percent of women and 6.4 percent of men were clinically obese," the ICRF said in a statement. Among those who did not eat meat, including fish-eaters, 2.7 percent of men and 4.8 percent of the women were obese. Non meat-eaters were also slimmer, with vegans the slimmest. The longer the time since someone had eaten meat, the slimmer he or she was.
"These data suggest that a meat-free diet is associated with a low prevalence of obesity," Key's group wrote.
